table_items.text: ACUTE ALCOHOL WITHDRAWAL MANAGEMENT FOR ADULT INPATIENTS
Type: Clinical Guideline Register No: 14039 Status: Public on ratification
Professionally Approved By Dr Kirthivasan Ramanathan, Clinical Director for Medicine
Executive Management Board Sign Off Date
Dr Chirag Oza, Consultant Gastroenterologist & Hepatologist, Clinical Lead Gastroenterology
Policy to be followed by (target staff)
Related Trust Policies (to be read in conjunction with)

data.text: Document Review History:

table_items.text: Dr Chirag Oza - Policy Review April 2018
Maria Richards – Clarification of dosing in appendix 1

data.text: Index
Appendix 1 Clinical Alcohol Withdrawal Assessment (CIWA-Ar) Chart Appendix 2 Dose Calculation
Purpose
This purpose of this clinical guideline is to:
standardise the prescription of detoxification for alcohol withdrawal in all adult patients admitted with, or experiencing, alcohol withdrawal
to minimise morbidity and mortality and maximise patient comfort through:
Scope
This policy is to be used by all doctors, nurses, pharmacists and Allied Health Professionals.
This policy covers adult inpatients experiencing acute alcohol withdrawal (18 years and above) in Broomfield Hospital. It excludes outpatients.

This policy should be considered in all adult patients at risk of acute alcohol withdrawal, as identified by AUDIT-C in the Nursing Assessment, or identified during medical/surgical clerking at the time of admission (acute or planned). However, the decision for detoxification should be made by a senior doctor who has experience in managing these patients.
Detoxification from alcohol in inpatients is usually indicated in the following cases:
Definitely indicated if weekly alcohol consumption exceeds 100 units/week
Probably required for patients drinking 60 to 100 units/week
Not usually needed when intake is less than 60 units a week but may be required

Patients with complex alcohol withdrawal (e.g. DTs (delirium tremens), seizures, hallucinations, etc.), should be admitted for inpatient management of alcohol withdrawal as per the guidelines set out in this policy.
Staff Training
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up to date.
During induction, staff will receive instruction on current policies and guidelines and how to access them.

Staff will receive training on how to use this policy on the wards. This will be undertaken as face to face training by the Alcohol Liaison Nurse. This will be mandatory for all doctors and nurses working on wards where patients are admitted for more than 24 hours.
Definitions
Alcohol withdrawal
4.1.1 This refers to a group of symptoms that may occur from suddenly stopping the use of alcohol after chronic or prolonged ingestion.

4.1.2 Symptoms and signs include (amongst others): Anxiety, agitation, irritability, depression, mood swings, insomnia, tremor of the hands, tongue, eyelids, fever (with or without infection), hypertension, tachycardia, sweating, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, pallor, dilated pupils, amongst others.
Delirium Tremens

4.2.1 Delirium tremens (DTs) is the most severe form of alcohol l withdrawal manifested by altered mental status (global confusion) and sympathetic overdrive (autonomic hyperactivity), which can progress to cardiovascular collapse.
4.2.2 DTs occur in about 5% of patients during withdrawal, usually 2-5 days after alcohol cessation or reduced alcohol intake.
4.2.3 DTs are fatal in 15-20% of inappropriately managed patients, whilst prophylactic and proactive sedation reduces mortality to 1-5%
4.2.4 Symptoms and signs include agitation, fever, hallucinations, confusion and seizures
Wernicke's Encephalopathy
4.3.1 This refers to the presence of neurological symptoms caused by biochemical lesions of the central nervous system, after exhaustion of B vitamin reserves, in particular thiamine.
4.3.2 It classically presents with the triad of confusion, ataxia and ophthalmoplegia, but only 10% of patients present with all three features.

4.3.3 It may develop rapidly or over a number of days. Inappropriately managed, it is the primary (or a contributory) cause of death in up to 20% of patients and results in permanent brain damage (Korsakoff's psychosis) in 85% of survivors.
Alcohol Units
4.4.1 One unit equates to 10ml or 8g of pure ethanol.
4.4.2 The alcohol by volume (ABV) of a drink equates to the number of units contained in one litre of that drink, e.g. a 1 litre bottle of 40% spirit will contain 40 units of alcohol.
Management – First 24 hours

Patients who have capacity must consent (verbally) to the alcohol detoxification regime. If they are not consenting, urgent senior clinician review is necessary to ascertain appropriateness of admission. For those patients who do not have capacity to consent, an MCA2 will need to be filled out, and consideration for DoLS (deprivation of liberty) made if indicated.
For the first  hours of the admission (initial assessment and treatment) the admitting doctor (FY1/FY2/CT/SpR/Consultant) should prescribe the following:
Adults <65 years with no co-existing risk factors*: chlordiazepoxide 25-50mg PO 2-4 hourly PRN as per CIWA-Ar chart with a maximum 250mg in 24 hours to be specified.
Elderly (age >65 years) or in presence of co-existing risk factors*: chlordiazepoxide 10 – 25 mg 2-4 hourly PRN, again with a maximum 250mg in 24 hours.
*co-existing risk factors are liver impairment, frailty, renal impairment, concomitant opioids
Pabrinex I+II, 2 pairs (= 4 vials) IV TDS for 2 days
Thiamine 100mg PO TDS for 30 days, after completion of IV Pabrinex
Diazepam 10-20mg (elderly 10mg) IV/PR PRN for seizures (patients are at risk of withdrawal seizures
Nurses are to assess the patient for the first 24 hours using a flexible regime via CIWA- Ar Withdrawal Scale (See Appendix 13.1 CIWA-Ar Assessment Tool), and administer chlordiazepoxide as follows:

table_items.text: Adults <65 years with no co-existing risk factors* ASSESS CIWA-Ar EVERY 2-4 HOURS
Adults ≥65 years and/or with co- existing risk factors* ASSESS CIWA-Ar HOURLY
Administer chlordiazepoxide 25mg STAT (then give 25mg every 2-4 hours PRN. Maximum daily dose of 250mg in 24 hours)
Administer chlordiazepoxide 10mg STAT (then give 10mg every 2-4 hours PRN. Maximum daily dose of 250mg in 24 hours)
Administer chlordiazepoxide 50mg STAT (then give 50mg every 2-4 hours PRN. Maximum daily dose of 250mg in 24 hours)
Administer chlordiazepoxide 25mg STAT (then give 25mg every 2-4 hours PRN. Maximum daily dose of 250mg in 24 hours)

data.text: *co-existing risk factors are liver impairment, frailty, renal impairment, concomitant opioids
Patient should be assessed more frequently if scores remain high despite treatment, or if patient clinically appears to still be withdrawing
If patient is pregnant, ensure Obstetric team have been notified of admission
Management after the first 24 hours
After the first 24 hours, stop the chlordiazepoxide prescribed on a PRN basis.
Calculate total chlordiazepoxide administered during the first 24 hours and start a regular reducing regime accordingly, following instructions below for reducing regimen.
Reduce the total dose needed in 24 hours by 20%, then divide this dose into 4 equal doses and prescribe as a fixed QDS dose for the detoxification regime.
Continue to reduce the total daily dose by 20% daily over the following 5-7 days, and then stop the chlordiazepoxide (this is as an inpatient).
Assess patient as per CIWA-Ar withdrawal scale every 4 hours. Review patients daily. A sign that the patient is receiving the right dose is that the CIWA scores should be reducing over time.

Patients should not normally be prescribed PRN chlordiazepoxide after the initial 24 hours. A patient who is still showing withdrawal symptoms and may need further PRN should be assessed and their detoxification regime reviewed. A patient who seems over- sedated after first 24 hours should also have the reducing regime reviewed by review team.
Difficult to Control Patients

These patients should be urgently reviewed by Medical Staff. Consider switching to IV diazepam – may be administered as a bolus at a rate of 5mg/min through a peripheral (large vein) or central route. A dose of 5-10mg every 30-60mins may be given until symptoms subside or the patient is sedated (max 30mg in 24hours). These patients should be managed either on MHDU or ITU.
In elderly patients use half the recommended diazepam dose. Beware of airway and respiratory complications.
For patients with liver failure, IV lorazepam 1-2mg over 5mins (max 6hourly) may be used instead of diazepam (allowing for drug availability).
Consider using haloperidol PO/IM 5mg TDS as an alternative option
Consider extending the PRN dosing beyond 24hours in patients with delirium tremens
Consider using a longer withdrawal regimen if unable to stabilise after 24 hours
Discuss with the senior medical team and consider consulting with Psychiatric Liaison.
Strict cardiac & airways monitoring is essential. If this cannot be achieved then avoid IV sedation

Patients who are agitated or violent secondary to delirium tremens may require the presence of hospital security to ensure their own, other patient's, visitors and staff safety. In an emergency situation security are to be contacted using the 6666 bleep system. If long term security is required this is to be arranged with the Trust Security Manager, with advice as to what may be required from the LSMS (Local Security Management Specialist).
Discharge Planning
The detoxification regimen should be completed before the patient is discharged.
Make it clear on the prescription chart that chlordiazepoxide stops after the last day of the detoxification regime
At Consultant's discretion, patients can be given up to a maximum of 20mg chlordiazepoxide in discharge medication. Please specify it is not to be continued after this.
Patients who discharge themselves against medical advice should not be supplied with chlordiazepoxide to take away, and they should sign the Trust self discharge form.
All patients undergoing detoxification should be discharged on thiamine 100mg three times daily.
It is important that the GP is informed on the discharge letter not to add chlordiazepoxide to patients' repeat medications.
Breech Reporting
Those patients who come to harm (withdrawal seizure, DTs, etc.) during their admission will require a Datix completed.
Audit & Monitoring
Pharmacy will monitor all acute prescriptions for chlordiazepoxide, and any concerns will be reported to the physician responsible for the patient.

Annual audit will be undertaken to monitor patient length of stay and any adverse events. This will be undertaken by the Gastroenterology department, and presented at one of the weekly Gastroenterology teaching sessions.
All reported (datixed) risk events will be reviewed at least annually and the Consultant Gastroenterologist & Hepatologist will report any findings/trends to the Clinical Director.
Useful Contacts

References
Taylor, D; Paton, C; Kerwin R (2007). The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines 9th Edition BNF 65. September 2013
NICE guidelines: Alcohol-use disorders: physical complications (June 2010)
NICE guidelines: Nutrition support in adults (November 2012)
Parker AJ, Marshall EJ, Ball DM; Diagnosis and management of alcohol use disorders. BMJ. 2008 Mar 1; 336(7642):496-501.
Health and Social Care Information Centre: http://www.hscic.gov.uk/article/
Appendix 1
Clinical Alcohol Withdrawal Assessment (CIWA-Ar) Chart This chart is to be used in conjunction with the assessment questions overleaf
Frequency of Observations:  2 Hourly □   4 Hourly □

table_items.text: Surname (or affix label): Forename(s): Date of Birth: Hospital Number: NHS Number:
Assess and rate each of the following:

Dose given (mg) Please sign drug chart If CIWA-Ar = 10-14 Give 25mg chlordiazepoxide (or 10mg if ≥65 yrs and/or with co-existing risk factors) If CIWA-Ar = ≥15 Give 50mg chlordiazepoxide (or 25mg if ≥65 yrs and/or with co-existing risk factors)

data.text: Using the descriptions and questions overleaf, rate each withdrawal symptom, then add the scores together

table_items.text: Nausea and Vomiting: Ask “Do you feel sick to your stomach? Have you vomited?” Observation 0 no nausea with no vomiting 1 mild nausea with no vomiting 2 3 4 intermittent nausea with dry heaves 5 6 7 constant nausea, frequent dry heaves and vomiting

Tactile (touch) Disturbances: Ask “Have you any itching, pins and needles sensations, any burning, any numbness, or do you feel bugs crawling on or under your skin?” Observation 0 none 1 very mild itching, pins and needles, burning or numbness 2 mild itching, pins and needles, burning or numbness 3 moderate itching, pins and needles, burning or numbness 4 moderately severe hallucinations 5 severe hallucinations 6 extremely severe hallucinations 7 continuous hallucinations

Tremor: Arms extended and fingers spread wide apart. Observation 0 no tremor 1 not visible, but can be felt fingertip to fingertip 2 3 4 moderate, with patients' arms extended 5 6 7 severe, even with arms not extended

Auditory (hearing) Disturbances: Ask “Are you more aware of sounds around you? Are they harsh? Do they frighten you? Are you hearing anything that is disturbing you? Are you hearing things you know are not there?” Observation 0 not present 1 very mild harshness or ability to frighten 2 mild harshness or ability to frighten 3 moderate harshness or ability to frighten 4 moderately severe hallucinations 5 severe hallucinations 6 extremely severe hallucinations 7 continuous hallucinations
Paroxysmal Sweats: Observation 0 no sweat visible 1 barely perceptible sweating, palms moist 2 3 4 beads of sweat obvious on forehead 5 6 7 drenching sweats

Visual (sight) Disturbances: Ask “Does the light appear to be too bright? Is it's colour different? Does it hurt your eyes? Are you seeing anything that's disturbing you? Are you seeing anything that you know is not there?” Observation 0 not present 1 very mild sensitivity 2 mild sensitivity 3 moderate sensitivity 4 moderately severe hallucinations 5 severe hallucinations 6 extremely severe hallucinations 7 continuous hallucinations
Anxiety: Ask “Do you feel nervous?” Observation 0 no anxiety, at ease 1 mildly anxious 2 3 4 moderately anxious or guarded, so anxiety is suggested 5

Headache, Fullness in Head: Ask “Does your head feel different? Does it feel like there is a band around your head? Do not rate for dizziness or light-headedness. Otherwise, rate severity. Observation 0 not present 1 very mild 2 mild
6 7 equivalent to acute panic states as seen in severe delirium or acute schizophrenic states
3 moderate 4 moderately severe 5 severe 6 very severe 7 extremely severe
Agitation: Observation 0 normal activity 1 somewhat more than normal activity 2 3 4 moderately fidgety and restless 5 6 7 paces back and forth during interview, or thrashes about

Orientation and Clouding of Sensorium: Ask "What day is this? Where are you? Who am I?" 0 orientated and can do serial additions 1 cannot do serial additions or is uncertain about date 2 disorientated for date by no more than 2 calendar days 3 disorientated for date by more than 2 calendar days 4 disorientated for place or person

data.text: Appendix 2
DOSE CALCULATION
Simple Dose Equivalence:
Diazepam 10 mg = chlordiazepoxide 25mg = lorazepam 1mg
Chlordiazepoxide dose calculation after 24 hours:
After the ‘first 24 hours', stop the chlordiazepoxide prescribed on a PRN basis.
Calculate total chlordiazepoxide administered during the first 24 hours and start a regular reducing regime accordingly.
Reduce the total dose needed in 24 hours by 20%, then divide this dose into 4 equal doses and prescribe as a fixed QDS dose for the detoxification regime
Continue to reduce the total daily dose by 20% daily over the following 5-7 days, and then stop the chlordiazepoxide (this is as an inpatient).

Chlordiazepoxide should not been administered at the same time as other benzodiazepines (e.g. diazepam and lorazepam), but if other benzodiazepines have been given, the equivalent separate doses should be added to calculate the 24 hour total dose

table_items.text: EXAMPLE DOSE CALCULATOR Record dose and time of any benzodiazepine (eg. chlordiazepoxide) given in 24 hour period Continue to reduce the total daily dose by 20% daily over the following 5-7 days, and then stop the chlordiazepoxide
Total dose of Benzodiazepines at 24 hours NB: Convert other benzodiazepines to equivalent dose of chlordiazepoxide
[Total dose reduced by 20%} divided by 4 = QDS dose for next day
